true.say: Hello, I was sent here by Johannes Gutenberg to ask more about research publications.
true.page: Oh wonderful! Not many pupils in this town are interested in such information! Ask away!
true.say: Could you tell me what exactly a research journal is?
true.page: A research journal is a sort of a publication usually geared toward a specific field of study.
They allow for researchers to write about the work they’ve been doing and allows for other researchers to review the work published.
true.say: How would I know which is a good journal and which is a bad one?
true.page: That can be difficult. You often want to pay close attention to the level of scrutiny the work published in the journal is held to.
Peer-reviewed journals are usually a reliable source, but you should always doubt what is published!
true.say: How can I determine between science articles in journals and non-science articles?
true.page: Science articles are normally clear and unambiguous.
The results of such scientific works should be reproducible, predictable, and testable... to name a few key features.
Non-science articles typically rely on things not measurable, or unquantifiable sources.
true.say: You’ve answered all my questions! Thank you!
true.page: Not a problem! It was wonderful to chat about such things again. Please come by again and we’ll chat more!

dialog.page: Stop by if you have any questions.
